#Text=2. Recent Progress of Antiprotozoan Agents
#Text=2.1. Anti-Giardiasis
#Text=Giardiasis is caused by the protozoan parasite G. intestinalis ( also known as G. lamblia or G. duodenalis ) .
#Text=It is also known by the common name “ beaver fever , ” because this infection was reported in campers who drank contaminated water that was inhabited by beavers .
#Text=Giardiasis is the most common protozoan infection in human beings , and it occurs in both developing and industrialized countries .
#Text=Its global incidence is believed to range between 20 % – 60 % , with 2 % – 7 % incidence in industrialized nations .
#Text=Giardia intestinalis was first described in 1681 after the Dutch microscopist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek observed the protozoan in his own diarrheic stools .
#Text=This disease is often prevalent in poor countries and communities that have untreated water , inadequate sanitation , and poor dietary status .
#Text=The infection is caused by fecal – oral transmission and initiated by the ingestion of infectious cysts from contaminated water or through person-to-person contact .
#Text=After excystation , flagellated trophozoites colonize the upper small intestine , where they attach to the epithelial lining but do not invade the mucosa .
#Text=The duration of Giardia infection is variable ; however , chronic infection and reinfection commonly occur .
#Text=Approximately 50 % of the symptoms classically associated with giardiasis are asymptomatic including diarrhea , abdominal pain , nausea , vomiting , and anorexia .
#Text=However , infected individuals can also develop extraintestinal and postinfectious complications .
#Text=Chronic extraintestinal sequelae may affect the joints , skin , eyes , and central nervous system , but the underlying mechanisms are unknown .

#Text=According to research data , Giardia has eight distinct genetic assemblages labelled as assemblage “ A ” through “ H ” , and assemblages “ A ” and “ B ” are responsible for infection in humans .
#Text=Three classes of drugs are currently used for the treatment of giardiasis : metronidazole , mepacrine analogs , and nitrofurans , such as furazolidone (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=) .
#Text=Metronidazole is the most widely used drug for the treatment of giardiasis globally and it is generally effective and well-tolerated .

#Text=However , the United States Food and Drug Administration ( FDA ) has not yet approved this drug for the treatment of Giardia infection because of its toxicity and major side effects , such as seizures , ataxia , peripheral neuropathy , transient myopia , gastric mucosal irritation , sperm damage , and hematuria .
#Text=Tinidazole is an N1-position modified 5-nitro imidazole , which has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of giardiasis .
#Text=Nitazoxanide ( NTZ ) belongs to an emerging class of 5-nitrothiazole compounds with potential antigiardial activity .
#Text=However , although NTZ is generally well tolerated , some adverse effects such as abdominal pain , diarrhea , and nausea limit the safe use for human beings .
#Text=Mepacrine is no longer available in the United States , and it is being replaced in most of its applications with safer and more specific drugs .

#Text=Furazolidone also has serious side effects , such as gastrointestinal disturbances , hemolytic anemia , disulfiram-like reactions to alcohol , and hypersensitivity reactions , as well as evidence of tumorigenicity in rodent studies .
#Text=Furthermore , G. lamblia resistance to this drug has also been reported .
#Text=Therefore , research focusing on the development of novel , alternative drugs for the treatment of giardiasis is highly desirable .
#Text=In view of these considerations , researchers have designed and synthesized some novel molecules for the treatment of giardiasis , their results are summarized in Table 1 .
